keyTakeAways: Yemen’s Houthi authorities have detained around 20 United Nations staff in a raid on a UN-run facility in Sanaa.
The detainees include at least five Yemeni employees and 15 international personnel; 11 were briefly questioned and later released.
The Houthi forces confiscated all communication equipment, including computers, phones, and servers, inside the facility.
The staff belong to several UN agencies, including the World Food Programme (WFP), UNICEF, and the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA).
This incident follows a sustained crackdown on UN and international aid organizations in Sanaa, Hodeidah, and Saada province.
The UN has reported over 50 staff members detained since the conflict began, with at least 21 arrested since August 31, 2025.
The Houthis accuse detained staff of espionage on behalf of the United States and Israel, a claim the UN has denied.
The UN has suspended operations in Saada and relocated its top humanitarian coordinator from Sanaa to Aden in response to prior detentions.
UN Secretary-General spokesperson Stephane Dujarric criticized the Houthi accusations as 'dangerous and unacceptable' and called for the immediate release of detained staff.
The incident occurs amid a worsening humanitarian crisis in Yemen, where over 10 years of conflict have left millions dependent on international aid.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a latest escalation of a prolonged conflict, Yemen’s Houthi authorities have detained approximately 20 United Nations staff in a raid on a UN facility in Sanaa. The detainees include both Yemeni and international personnel from agencies such as the World Food Programme, UNICEF, and OCHA. Houthi forces confiscated all communication equipment, and the UN has consistently denied allegations of espionage against its staff. This incident follows a pattern of sustained detentions since August 2025, with over 50 UN staff and international NGO employees affected. The UN has suspended operations in Saada and relocated its top humanitarian coordinator to Aden in response. UN officials, including Jean Alam and Stephane Dujarric, have called for the immediate release of all detainees and condemned the Houthi accusations as 'dangerous and unacceptable,' amid a deepening humanitarian crisis in Yemen.
title: Yemen’s Houthis detain 20 UN staff in latest raid
